content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this a repeated game with incomplete information about my opponent's strategy. In such situations, it is common to use strategies like Tit-for-Tat or Grim Trigger. However, since there are slightly different payoffs for each outcome, I might adjust these strategies slightly.

Here's the reasoning:

1. If both of us choose R in every round, we will earn 45$ per round. That's a total of 75 * 45 = 3375$. This is the best outcome if my opponent follows the same strategy.

2. If I always choose R and my opponent chooses B in each round, I get nothing for 75 rounds, which gives me a total of 0$.

3. If I always choose B and my opponent chooses R, I get 35$ per round, totaling 75 * 35 = 2625$. This is still not the best outcome but it's closer than choosing R all the time against an opponent who chooses B all the time.

4. If we both choose B in every round, we each get 40$ per round, totaling 75 * 40 = 3000$. This is the second-best outcome if my opponent follows the same strategy.

Considering these outcomes and the fact that I don't know my opponent's strategy, I would choose a mixed strategy where I randomly pick R or B in each round. However, since choosing R gives me a higher payoff when my opponent chooses B (35$ vs 0$), I might lean slightly towards choosing R more often. In terms of ratios, let's say I pick R around 60% of the time and B around 40% of the time. This way, if my opponent is also following a mixed strategy, there's a higher chance that we end up with me picking R when they pick B, which results in a higher payoff for me (35$ vs 0$).

My choice would be to randomly pick R or B, but slightly more inclined towards R. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I made a mistake by choosing R when my opponent chose B. To minimize the chances of making the same mistake again and to maximize my overall payoff in the long run, I will switch my strategy slightly. Instead of picking R or B randomly with a 60% and 40% probability respectively, I will now pick R around 30% of the time and B around 70% of the time.

My new choice for this round would be to pick B. {B}
